This. You have to be able to know when to put it down. Seems like OP has to much on their plate. Come the end of the day, say 5pm, my brain just starts to flicker. Op is just going, no boundaries on where to stop, and it keeps overlapping; the adderall is a crutch to get them through.

If they are not convicted of anything, then they walk free. It's highly unlikely that are not convicted of anything based on everything they were charged with. If they plead down and try to consolidate charges they are going to have to play ball with the prosecutor. I seriously doubt they walk away without some jail time with what they were charged with; that's some pretty heavy charges. If that "person" doesn't already have an Attorney, they need to get one. Good luck to them, seriously.
Jail. The length with determine the outcome of the case and what charges they are convicted of. There are sentencing guidelines for each charge. Your jurisdiction will set the min/max for terms.

WRITING.TITLE: Video Games
WRITING.TEXT:
Friendly reminder to BOLO for VIDEO GAMES.
I know a lot do, but video games is an easy way to get into this business. You can find games at garage sales/estate sales for next to nothing and sell them for $10-$20-$40+ on eBay.
I just spent a few hours browsing eBay to calculate a lot of Nintendo 64 games for sale near me. The lot is for 30 games, various titles, and I concluded it's worth roughly $647.00 retail. The buyer has not responded to my negotiation attempts, but still goes to show the deals are out there.

I do actively search for rare and collectible books, including Bibles.
Printers did not start mass producing the Bible like they do now until the 70's and 80's; you should search for bibles before 1960. Even then it will depend on the design and style of the Bible. I don't like to spend more then $0.50-$1.00 for my books, unless I know what they will fetch, or I want it for my own personal collection.
Obviously more elaborate Bibles will be worth much more then generic Bibles. Condition is everything. Bibles in good condition can fetch a few hundred dollars.
This also goes for other religious texts as well. My wallet does not discriminate based on the origin of the dollar it holds.
Edit: The "good" ones are hard to come by. They will usually be the "family" Bible and be passed on. I'd try estate sales before going to the Goodwill. Also, if you can tie the Bible to a notable figure in history--goldmine. Good luck.
Haha! I didn't know that, but that's hilarious.
Right! I thought the same thing. That is a lot of money. You could just step out of your house and actually engage people for free, I hear that's how the old folks use to do things.

The "notes" are what you signed to take the loans out. They are legal contracts that bind you to repayment and give the lender the authority to seek collection and other remedial actions in the event you default on the loan.
Ideally they want you to pay. They put you in collections and you agreed to pay $200/mo to satisfy the balance of the loan, including any interest that accrued during the time it took to repay the loan.
I'm sorry but you agreed to it and signed the notes, sometimes called the Master Promissory Note, contractually binding you to repayment of the loan to received.

I couldn't even say, honestly. I have been doing this for close to 15 years.
I easily put in 1-2 hours per day, 5-6 days a week doing my quick scans of the places I buy from.
If your looking to get into this I would suggest picking a category if items you enjoy first. Your research will be more fun and you will be able to focus more. Google is your best friend in this endeavor.
Knowing what your looking for, how much you should spend, and when to walk away are the three most important aspects of flipping. The worst thing to do is buy an item to high; you must know when you buy or walk away. I have seen items I know I can sell, but the price wasn't right, so I had to walk. Just be able to have enough knowledge to negotiate to a point where you can make money.

It really varies on how many items I come across. When I'm really moving I can average $2-300 per month. I've hit some good buys in the past and it's been as high as $3500.
It really depends on what you find and how much you have on your laundry list to look for. The more you have on your list the more options you have to buy.

Interest is going to continue to accrue. He didn't agree to settle the account for the $6,000, he agreed to pay the entire balance at a monthly amount, they agreed to a monthly payment.
Yes, 30 payments of $200 is $6,000, but each month interest is going to get tacked on.
Your going to have to pay over the monthly amount to pay down the interest before it accrues.
I'm sorry your in this position.

How large is he artist? If it's considerable you'd might be better going with the traditional auction route.
If the artist isn't "on" eBay, that doesn't mean there isn't a following. Not being able to find items is sometimes good because there is nothing to compete with your item.
What is the artists name?
What is the pieces name(s)?

I do both. It really just depends on the item.
I've bought online and sold in person. I've bought in person and sold online.
Usually I will buy in person and sell online. Like I said I get a lot of my items from garage sales/Estate sales. I have though bought off Letgo/Offer Up/Craigslist and have sold the item on EBay.
I sell majority of my items on EBay.

A lot of the business aspects were a struggle for some of my friends who went solo after graduation. It's not that simple to graduate, pass the bar, get licensed, and then jump into your own thing; there are a lot of moving parts to become successful.

Anything I can buy low and sell high. Pretty cliche, but that's how you make your money. I don't buy anything I can't make at least $20, unless it's a really low buy I don't mind taking the risk for under.
I do have a laundry list of items I look for at garage sales and estate sales. I've been doing this for some time so I know what is what and the price the item usually will sell for.

Michigan is a no-fault state. Prices go up because PI Law suits generate millions for accident victims. Insurance companies have to pay out, so they raise rates and premiums. No-fault has its benefits, but there are also a lot of pitfalls that come with it.
Looks like the wood just split, you might start to get some sagging. I would call a structural contractor out there to see if they could give you a free quote.

I would write it like a cover letter, but slightly modified. I would most definitely put in the email your friend's name and make that connection. I would send your resume as well just to cut an email out on his side requesting it--don't want to waste his time.

I did like this one, but I felt the "IT" was slightly lost with the "I"design.

This is another jurisdictional legal question. In some places the landlord must furnish a suitable living environment, and in other jurisdictions they don't--only occupation. Same thing when the tenant leaves. I know a lot of property management companies will tack on cleaning fees, most of which can be mitigated and tossed.

Welllllll...who has that laying around?
The $250 is bullshit. It's probably the cost his Attorney charged him to draft the new lease.
This may be a jurisdictional legal question actually. I would call a real estate attorney that offers free 30min consultation near you and ask them if there are any jurisdictional impediments that would restrict a landlord from charging a "contracting fee" to a new tenant; they should be able to tell you off the top of their head. If they want you to come in, call another, and do so until someone gives you a flat answer.
I get the first of the month rent part, that is standard. It's not a down payment though, even though it's damn near close to a down payment.

Your lender will have a requirement sometimes. If you don't have a lender, then I would suggest replacement value.
The market price is "iffy" to me because the market always fluctuates. If your home burns down or gets blown away by a tornado, the market is going to respond favorably when you list a brand new home for sale. But if you get sold on market value, the market could be down and you may not be able to even build a new home.
You could increase the coverage also if you have property (wedding rings/etc) you'd like to include if lost or stolen.

It's like a re-up on the deposit. If it was the same two tenants I'd say BS, but he doesn't know them, even if you thumb up them. I would have them negotiate with the landlord to term this as a deposit, to which they could receive a refund following termination of the lease, otherwise I'd tell him either he can have his units rented or vacant. He just wants to make more money that's all. I really wouldn't baulk at it to much, $250 is pretty cheap. Usually your going to pay $500 deposit plus one months rent.

I like the 6th logo (blue w/ black ball).
The name is clearly visible and legible. The logo design is engaging and made take a second look to see if that really was a ball or just a figment of imagination. I like the colors as well. I'd be curious to see it with red; I feel red against black really makes things stand out.

Your dads a lawyer...he gives us all bad names, screw him. You could report him to the ethics committee of your state for mishandling of funds. He might already have a bank account in your name, who knows maybe even some credit cards...If you suspect anything I'd pull your credit and go to the cops and find another attorney. You can find Attorneys who will give 30min free consultations.
